fields.description:
We use Crucible with Subversion to perform post-commit reviews.

If we add two Subversion changesets/revisions to a single review, the first which creates a file and the second which modifies that same file, then Crucible only shows the file changes for review, it doesn't show the file addition.

This is problematic because it means that some changes may sneak through unreviewed.

As a result, our reporting forces the use of separate reviews for file additions, which is a source of difficulty for our users. It's particularly unpleasant when a file addition must only be approved with subsequent modifications, but the tool requires that approval to be separated across reviews.
fields.summary: Crucible can't review file additions together with subsequent changes

{noformat}

I have a patch file with 41 files, with numerous changes in most of them and it seems that the error appears every time I tried to add that patch.

Moreover, if that fails, and I try to anchor manually, I get: 

{noformat}
Crucible tried to anchor your patch to 'DEPOT', but there was conflicting content in '/filepath/...' at revision '2519999'. You may not be able to see full context diffs. 
{noformat}

This happens for a file where all the contect was removed (a deleted file).

Then if I have a UTF-8 encoded file with BOM (but no other UTF-8 characters) in the Perforce Depot and my patch file simply indicates deleting all lines, but the patch file is pure ASCII file without BOM on in the very first line, then anchoring files.

If BOM is present as well in the patch file, then it works.

If I convert the file in Perforce Depot to ASCII (removing BOM), then the same patch works.

I have a workaround, but it would be good to see what Atlassian thinks of the case. Is this a bug?

fields.description:
Currently, when we create a review using the "Explore Repositories" option, the file tree shows outstanding files and directories in all branches in the repository at once. This can get very confusing if files have been moved or deleted in one branch, but not in another.

Typically, when reviewing a new feature it is much easier to select all of the files in the file tree, rather than selecting each commit from the branch where the feature is being developed. A new feature often has a large number of commits, so using "Browse Changesets" requires quite a few clicks. It would be nice to have a branch select drop-down in "Explore Repositories", similar to the "Browse Changesets" view, which would only display files from the latest version of the selected branch (the mainline, or another feature branch before being merged into the mainline).

I apologize if this issue has been resolved in a recent version (we're currently using 2.7.11). I don't believe it has though. Our system administrators are often overwhelmed with project-level administration for JIRA and Crucible, and therefore do not get a chance to upgrade our installations very frequently (see JRA-3156).

fields.description:
*Scenario:*
A code review is created and sent out to the reviewers. One of the reviewers, during his review, enters comments, marks them as Defects, and chooses Rankings and Classifications.

Next, during peer review (where reviewers are gathered) run by the Moderator everyone's comments are reviewed/discussed. In discussion it may be agreed that some of the comments marked as defects in fact should not be defects, but only valid comments, and others that should indeed be defects are improperly Ranked & Classified, or don't have a JIRA issue created for them yet.

Nowadays, only the reviewer that entered the comment can modify it (change defect ranking / classification) and create JIRA issues based on this comment. What if the reviewer leaves the company?

*Suggestion:*
The review Author and/or Moderator should also be able to edit (mark / unmark comments as defects, change defect rankings and classifications), to delete comments, and to create JIRA issues based on another person's comments.
fields.summary: Moderator should be able to edit/delete comments and create issues

fields.description:
We're using Crucible 2.9.1 running on a Debian GNU/Linux system, connecting to a PostgreSQL 8.3 database.

FishEye/Crucible keeps a number of database connections open, in an "idle in transaction" state. These transactions hold a number of AccessShare table locks. This causes a problem when our database tries to run a "VACUUM FULL" maintenance job on the Crucible database, since VACUUM FULL attempts to get a AccessExclusive lock, which it can't do when there are AccessShare locks held on the same tables. This then causes further queries to stall because they're waiting for AccessShare locks on the same table the vacuum process is waiting for an AccessExclusive lock on.

I've attached some process listings and information from pg_locks which demonstrate the issue.

Ideally, Crucible should be closing the transactions when they're not in use, thus releasing the locks.

Our workaround for now is to stop Crucible before vacuuming the DB, although obviously this is not ideal.
fields.summary: Database connections in "idle in transaction" state

1. We basically walk the entire comment trees (for each FRX and at the top level - all of which will be loaded into memory) to get the count (see stacktrace below). And we do that for each participant. 
2. we often calculate for no reason, for example, in {{reviewUpdatedResponse.jsp}} which doesn't appear to be used by the client javascript
3. we often calculate redundantly in JSPs, where we test {{participantDO.authoredCommentCount > 0}} and then call {{participantDO.authoredCommentCount}} again (which will result in two traversals of the entire comment tree of the review).

Implement this as a single query on the db:
{code}
 count (*) from cru_comment where user_id = ? and review_id = ? and cru_deleted = false and cru_draft = false
{code}

fields.description:
Due to the removal of the JiraIssueCache in 2.9.0, Crucible are now calling out to JIRA once per comment to get the *review level* (Linked Issue) JIRA issue (ie. the exact same call, once per comment).

We have decided that this is not a blocker for the 2.9.0 release because:
* it seems to be fast enough in the happy case (when JIRA is fast)
* in the very sad case, the cache wouldnt have helped us anyway, so its not a new problem

There are however a couple of cases were we have introduced a performance regression:
* JIRA is just slow, but still returning Issues - the cache would have helped here
* JIRA was working before (cache is warm) and then it goes down
fields.summary: Crucible calls out to JIRA once per Comment

fields.description:
DefaultReviewManager.deleteReview inserts a state of "Deleted" into the state change log, which is technically not a valid state for the state manager. This is a special case, because the review no longer exists, except for its entries in the log, so the invalid state name shouldn't cause problems. However in one support case a review is marked as deleted in the log, but is also still present in other tables, causing it to be loaded as a candidate for the activity stream, causing errors to be logged.

work needed here:

1. is there any way that the id of a deleted review could be accidentally being reused?
2. make the deleted state a valid state
3. check the transaction semantics around deletion
fields.summary: deleteReview has marked a review as deleted in the state change log, but left the review in the db

fields.description:
Hi mates.

A customer've discovered the following problems with git changesets containing file permissions changes in Crucible version 2.8.0 and Stash version 1.2.2:

1. If a single git changeset contains only file permissions changes, Crucible does not allow the changeset to be added to a review. The changeset is labeled as a "metadata-only" changeset in Crucible.

2. If a single git changeset contains a file with a permissions change, and a different file with a content change, Crucible fails to add the changeset to a review. The checkbox for the changeset in the Add Content dialog turns red and only files with content changes are added to the Crucible review.
fields.summary: Problems with git changesets containing permissions changes in Crucible

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*

# Create a new file in a git repository named file1.txt. The new file is committed on changeset 9374886d6ae61a43694949d1006f7b4b00886171.
# Modify file1.txt. The modification is committed on changeset daa4f4e5b6d6cadc9389445d5237bd51607c263d.
# Create a Crucible review. Use Search for Files to find file1.txt.
# In the Add Content to Review window, click the checkbox next to revision daa4f4e5b6d6cadc9389445d5237bd51607c263d of file1.txt. 

At this point, note that the checkbox for revision 9374886d6ae61a43694949d1006f7b4b00886171 of file1.txt *is also automatically checked, even though it was not clicked*. However, *the revision automatically checked wasn't really added to the review*. 

Three things prove this:
* The Review Coverage report shows revision 9374886d6ae61a43694949d1006f7b4b00886171 of file1.txt as *not under review* and revision daa4f4e5b6d6cadc9389445d5237bd51607c263d of file1.txt as *under review*.
* The EyeQL below returns file1.txt, indicating that revision 9374886d6ae61a43694949d1006f7b4b00886171 of file1.txt *is not in any review*.
{noformat}
select revisions where (not in any review) and (csid=9374886d6ae61a43694949d1006f7b4b00886171)
{noformat}
* The EyeQL below returns an empty list, indicating that revision daa4f4e5b6d6cadc9389445d5237bd51607c263d of file1.txt *is in a review*.
{noformat}
select revisions where (not in any review) and (csid=daa4f4e5b6d6cadc9389445d5237bd51607c263d)
{noformat}

*Workaround:*
Go back to the review, click Edit Details, Add Content, Search for Files, search for file1.txt, and then uncheck and check again the checkbox of the revision 9374886d6ae61a43694949d1006f7b4b00886171.

By doing this, the Review Coverage report will show both revisions under review, and the EyeQL queries above will return an empty list indicating that both revisions are in a review.
fields.summary: Search for Files to add content to review is not working correctly

fields.description:
Some files are not included in the source code reviews in Crucible at all. This scenario ends up in file not being shown in review at all (Crucible used with SVN):
1. File1 exists in SVN prior to date A
2. File1 is renamed to File2 (between dates A and B)
3. File3 is created from File2 as a result of SVN copy (between dates A and B)
4. Review is created for changes between dates A and B

Result: the review shows File1 as to be deleted in review and File3 as a modified file. File2 is not shown at all. This means that "a new file" that has been created between dates A and B is not shown in the review at all and as such is not being reviewed, although all changed files should be reviewed. There should at least be some way to notice that a new file has appeared in the repository - now there is none.
fields.summary: SVN copy and modifications are not always included in reviews correctly

fields.description:
This occurred on an OnDemand instance, however it is a more generic problem:

STEPS TO REPLICATE:

* Set up a JIRA workflow that requires a valid crucible review for all associated commits
* Create a commit that does not contain any text (i.e. just creating a directory) and reference a JIRA issue

RESULT:

It won't be possible to create a review for that commit (error is IllegalArgumentException - changeset must contain a text file change.) As such you won't be able to proceed through the workflow

DESIRED RESULT:

It would be nice if the workflow condition allowed that commit to be an exception, as it isn't possible to create a review from it.
fields.summary: Allow creation of reviews for commits with created/deleted directories

fields.description:
Compared to dedicated backup software, Crucible's handling of scheduled backups is simplistic: their status is not stored anywhere (FE-1539), no notifications are sent if they fail (CRUC-5677), and if left unchecked, they could fill up disk space (CRUC-3106).  

And mere presence of a backup is not a guarantee that it's complete -- there was at least one case where backup would not contain all requested data: CRUC-2752

I propose to
- store the status (OK/Failed/Warnings) and execution log of every backup job
- expose those in the UI
- send (configurable) e-mail notifications (f.e. if status was not OK)
- allow the admin to delete old backups from UI

Current workaround is to monitor log file for certain error messages, f.e.

"BackupJob-execute - Error performing backup:"
"Caches will NOT be included in this backup."
fields.summary: Admin-friendly scheduled backups

fields.description:
Trying to create a pre-commit review with the result of `svn diff`. When I select the .diff from the file manager and click upload, I get a message similar to:

{code}
Crucible tried to anchor your patch to 'TREE', but there 
was conflicting content in 'path/to/file.h' at revision '123' 
{code}

There is no indication of what course of action needs to be taken to resolve this type of issue in the logs or the message itself that I've found.

Currently there is no workaround that I've found other than mailing around a .diff to the intended reviewers. Arguably, this is not actually a workaround with regards to a usable Crucible/Fisheye.
fields.summary: Patch anchoring and conflicting content

fields.description:
Hello,

We added the Jira as a trusted application to FishEye-CRUCIBLE and vice-versa, however, the issue persists.

The user has the necessary permissions to create the reviews. We also use Subversion - should we try adding its host name to the Trusted Applications list? Or is there anything else we can do to stop this error from occurring?

Please let me know if you need any further information.

We use FishEye-CRUCIBLE v2.4.3, Jira v4.0.1 and Subversion v1.6.5.

If you click on it, it'll take you to http://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download, which is the FishEye download page.

However, as you're using only Crucible, it should take you to the Crucible download page: http://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/download
